results.title: Sculpture Australia '69
results.brief_description: Australian sculptors discuss their attitudes towards modern sculpture. Artists shown at work include Norma Redpath creating the fountain for the Commonwealth Treasury, Steven Walker, Ken Reinhart, Robert Klippel, Clement Meadmore and Vincent Jomantis
results.description: Australian sculptors discuss their attitudes towards modern sculpture. Artists shown at work include Norma Redpath creating the fountain for the Commonwealth Treasury, Steven Walker, Ken Reinhart, Robert Klippel, Clement Meadmore and Vincent Jomantis

results.title: The Royal Silver Jubilee Exhibition Train
results.creator_credit: Michael Pearce, Peter Johnson and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A look at the Jubilee Exhibition train, housing 700 years of British history. Shows many of the exhibits and the stories behind them, and follows the progress of the train throughout Australia. Narrated by Stuart Wagstaff.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Pearce, Peter Johnson and Film Australia

results.title: Rooftopics
results.creator_credit: Antonio Colacino, Joe Scully and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Views of Sydney Harbour, city and inner suburbs from the roof-tops of various buildings. Shows scenes of everyday activities, roof gardens, play-grounds, swimming pools, street traffic, etc. viewed from above. Includes humorous animated sequence involving a man, his towel and a woman beside a swimming pool. No spoken commentary. Edited by Wayne Le Clos; photographed by George Alexander; music by Eric Gross and script by Antonio Colacino.

results.title: Roads at work
results.creator_credit: John Milson, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Transport in Australia”.
The importance of roads in Australia as a chief means of communication and a basis of the entire transport system. Shows their early haphazard growth from bullock wagon tracks, and the highly specialised work involved in organising major roadworks, and traffic today.

results.title: Reaching for the stars
results.creator_credit: Loch Townsend, John Martin-Jones, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian news and Information Bureau
results.brief_description: Shows Australian research in astronomy. Visits the observatory at Mount Stromolo, which houses big telescopes, cameras to map the skies, and the National Time Service. Goes on to show research on radio astronomy at the Radiophysics Laboratory (CSIRO), Sydney, and using Mills cross of stationary aerials and other devices. Pictures the windmill aerials at Dapto, used for tracking the sun

results.title: The Rail way
results.creator_credit: Greg Reading, Don Murray, Department of Transport and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A look at railways in Australia from Alice Springs to Kalgoorlie and Normanton. Shows trains serving the mining fields in central Queensland and the suburban trains of the big cities. Discusses problems brought about by different gauges throughout the country, and looks at the economic future of railways. Commentator Patsy Adam-Smith.

results.title: Project: Public Service
results.creator_credit: Shan Benson and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The Commonwealth Public Service as seen through the eyes of a school-boy preparing a project book on the work of the Service. The film also briefly outlines the functioning of the parliamentary system and role of the public servants.

results.title: Presidential tour
results.brief_description: The President of the U.S.A., Lyndon B. Johnson, and Mrs. Johnson visit Australia in October, 1966. Scenes in Canberra, Melbourne, Sydney, Brisbane and Townsville.

results.title: Power from the snow
results.creator_credit: Gunnar Isakson, John Martin-Jones and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: A survey of the Snowy Mountains Hydroelectric Scheme. Shows the commencement of work in 1949, surveying the area and design of the first part of the project. Culminates in the official opening by the Prime Minister of the new Munyang Power Station, a few miles downstream from Guthega Dam which supplies it with water. Work continues on this great project, estimated to take twenty-five years to complete. Over an area of 3,000 square miles, men and machines reshape the land to supply Australia with light, and power.
